contentrichtext.text: The '''Erdős–Borwein [[Mathematical constant|constant]]''' is the sum of the [[Reciprocal (mathematics)|reciprocals]] of the [[Mersenne prime|Mersenne number]]s. It is named after [[Paul Erdős]] and [[Peter Borwein]]. By definition it is: :<math>E=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{2^n-1}</math> which is approximately 1.60669 51524 15291 763… {{OEIS|A065442}}. ==Equivalent forms== It can be proven that the following forms all sum to the same constant: :<math> E=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{2^{n^2}}\frac{2^n+1}{2^n-1} </math> :<math> E=\sum_{m=1}^{\infty}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^{mn}} </math> :<math> E=1+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^n(2^n-1)} </math> :<math> E=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{\sigma_0(n)}{2^n} </math> where σ<sub>0</sub>(''n'') = ''d''(''n'') is the [[divisor function]], a [[multiplicative function]] that equals the number of positive [[divisor]]s of the number ''n''. To prove the equivalence of these sums, note that they all take the form of [[Lambert series]] and can thus be resummed as such.<ref>The first of these forms is given by {{harvtxt|Knuth|1998}}, ex. 27, p. 157; Knuth attributes the transformation to this form to an 1828 work of [[Thomas Clausen (mathematician)|Clausen]].</ref> ==Irrationality== Erdős in 1948 showed that the [[mathematical constant|constant]] ''E'' is an [[irrational number]].<ref>{{citation | last = Erdős | first = P. | author-link = Paul Erdős | journal = J. Indian Math. Soc. (N.S.) | mr = 0029405 | pages = 63–66 | title = On arithmetical properties of Lambert series | url = http://www.renyi.hu/~p_erdos/1948-04.pdf | volume = 12 | year = 1948}}.</ref> Later, Borwein provided an alternative proof.<ref>{{citation | last = Borwein | first = Peter B. | authorlink = Peter Borwein | doi = 10.1017/S030500410007081X | issue = 1 | journal = Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society | mr = 1162938 | pages = 141–146 | title = On the irrationality of certain series | volume = 112 | year = 1992}}.</ref> Despite its irrationality, the [[Binary numeral system|binary representation]] of the Erdős–Borwein constant may be calculated efficiently.<ref>{{harvtxt|Knuth|1998}} observes that calculations of the constant may be performed using Clausen's series, which converges very rapidly, and credits this idea to [[John Wrench]].</ref><ref>{{citation | last = Crandall | first = Richard | author-link = Richard Crandall | doi = 10.1515/integers-2012-0007 | journal = Integers | page = A23 | title = The googol-th bit of the Erdős–Borwein constant | volume = 12 | year = 2012}}.</ref> ==Applications== The Erdős–Borwein constant comes up in the [[average case analysis]] of the [[heapsort]] algorithm, where it controls the constant factor in the running time for converting an unsorted array of items into a heap.<ref>{{citation | last = Knuth | first = D. E. | author-link = Donald Knuth | edition = 2nd | location = Reading, MA | pages = 153–155 | publisher = Addison-Wesley | title = [[The Art of Computer Programming]], Vol. 3: Sorting and Searching | year = 1998}}.</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{MathWorld|urlname=Erdos-BorweinConstant|title=Erdos-Borwein Constant}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Erdos-Borwein Constant}} [[Category:Mathematical constants]] [[Category:Irrational numbers]] [[Category:Paul Erdős|Borwein constant]]
